PhD a Makanji Heeren MD a b Eisler Jesse MD jesse.eisler@hhchealth.org a c ⁎ a b c ⁎ jesse.eisler@hhchealth.org 12 2025 24 8 2025 24 497287 100786 24 3 2025 22 8 2025 22 8 2025 24 08 2025 01 10 2025 02 10 2025 © 2025 The Authors 2025 https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by-nc-nd/4.0/ This is an open access article under the CC BY-NC-ND license (http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by-nc-nd/4.0/). Background Spine procedures are becoming increasingly common and costly in the United States, thus managing fiscal responsibility with surgical outcomes is increasingly important. Reducing facility discharges following a lumbar fusion would not only reduce complications but could provide significant cost savings. Therefore, the purpose of this study is to identify both clinical factors (i.e. demographics, medical history factors) and patient reported outcome scores that were associated with an increased risk of a facility-based discharge following an elective 1 or 2 level lumbar fusion. Methods A total of 513 patients that underwent a 1- or 2-level lumbar fusion between June 2021 and June 2023 were included in this retrospective study. All patients completed their preoperative PROs and completed their medical history and physical prior to surgery. Using logistic regressions, independent variables associated with postoperative discharge to a skilled nursing facility were identified. Subsequent receiver operator curve analysis helped determine cut point values associated with a facility discharge. Results A total of 41 patients (7.9%) were discharged to a facility. Regression analysis identified 6 factors associated with a facility discharge. Three factors were related to clinical outcomes while the other 3 factors were obtained from patient reported outcomes measures. More specifically, PROMIS-10 Global physical (OR:0.17,95% CI 0.04–0.62, AUC:0.701) and mental health (OR:0.89,95% CI 0.83–0.95, AUC:0.813) T-scores below 40, and RAPT scores below 9 (OR:0.60,95% CI 0.48–0.74, AUC:0.814) were associated with facility-based discharges. Conclusions Patient reported outcomes measures provide significant discriminatory ability in combination with standard clinical metrics to identify patients at risk for a facility discharge following elective lumbar fusions. The results suggested that patient reported information concerning preoperative mobility, mental wellbeing, and support at home were more discriminatory than clinical metrics. The prevalence of lumbar fusions has dramatically increased in recent years, with some studies suggesting a 62% increase in spinal fusions between 2004 and 2015 [ 1 2 [3] [4] [5] 1 2 6 7 In an effort to reduce costs, medical centers have attempted to decrease postoperative lengths of stays and transition some procedures to same day outpatient surgical facilities [ 8 9 [10] [11] [12] 9 3 13 [14] [15] [16] [17] 3 13 A number of studies have investigated ways to preoperatively identify patients that are at risk for a SNF discharge following elective total joint arthroplasty [ 9 10 12 13 17 3 13 18 19 [20] [21] [22] Materials and methods This study was approved by the Institutional Review Board at our center. Patient records were included in this study if the patient was, between the ages of 35 and 89 years old, underwent an elective single or 2 level lumbar fusion between June 2021 and June 2023, required an inpatient stay, were seen for a preoperative optimization visit within the 30 days preceding their index surgery, and completed all of their preoperative PROs including: the Oswestry Disability Index (ODI), the PROMIS-10 Global Health Survey (PROMIS-10) [ 23 24 [25] [26] [27] It is important to note, that per standard of care at our institution all patients treated at our center must complete their preoperative optimization visit within 30 days of their lumbar fusion, and our preoperative spine PRO completion rate is 100%. The preoperative optimization visit includes: a complete history and physical, the completion of preoperative PROs, a discussion of modifiable risk factors within the patient’s history that should be addressed prior to surgery (recommendations could be made to delay surgery if necessary), and post discharge care planning. Patient records were excluded from this study if they patient had, undergone a revision procedure, underwent a staged fusion, underwent their fusion as a result of trauma or pathological condition (ie, cancer), required a fusion of 3 or more levels, had a diagnosed cognitive deficit, or had a skilled nursing facility listed as their primary residence prior to surgery. The primary outcome variable for this study was discharge to a facility. For the purposes of this study a discharge to a facility was defined as a post length of stay discharge to either a skilled nursing facility (SNF) or an inpatient rehabilitation facility (IRF). Demographic data, patient medical and social history, surgical planning data, in hospital stay, and preoperative PRO scores were all extracted from the patient’s electronic medical record. Continuous, normally distributed variables were presented as mean and standard deviation, while continuous non-normally distributed variables were presented as median and interquartile range (IQR). Data that consisted of count or binary data were presented as a percentage of the study cohort. To determine if there were statistically significant differences between study groups in regard to differences in demographics, PRO scores, and medical history, T-tests assuming unequal variance and chi-square contingency test were performed. Discussion Lumbar spine fusion provides a means of addressing complex spinal pathologies, and the number of surgeries conducted each year is only expected to rise [ 1 2 The results of this study indicated that 7.9% of patients that underwent elective 1 or 2 level lumbar fusions were discharged to a facility during the open period of this study. This rate is lower than has been previously described in literature [ 3 13 Furthermore, the results of the regression analyses indicated that a number of parameters were significantly associated with facility discharges for both the univariate and multivariate analyses. However, an important factor to discuss are the associated 95% confidence intervals. Parameters with extremely small ranges, tend to be an accurate representation of the general population, and thus the results would hold true beyond the study cohort, while wide confidence intervals demonstrate increased variability and may only hold true within the study cohort. For instance, the findings associated with the patient reported outcomes demonstrated limited variability, and thus indicate that these findings, would hold true for the general population further emphasizing the utility of PROs as a preoperative tool to identify patients for a poor outcome. Whereas other factors such as diabetes or female sex, show a much larger confidence interval, indicating that the generalizability may be limited. Additionally, the variability within the parameter could also be skewed. For example, diabetes is based on a diagnosis rather than an objective blood test in this study, so no distinction is made between patients with controlled or uncontrolled diabetes thus contributing to the larger confidence interval. It is also important to note that standard clinical factors such as BMI and CCI had larger confidence intervals than, the PRO measures indicating that the PRO measures had better discriminatory value. While the majority of current literature focuses on preoperative and inpatient variables to understand which variables are associated with a SNF discharge; this work focused solely on identifying preoperative risk factors associated with facility discharges [ 3 13 19 3 10 13 29 3 13 Unlike other studies that have looked at SNF discharges based on preoperative factors this study also included the results of patients reported outcomes. Inclusion of PRO scores in the multivariate regression model increased the r 2 20 21 14 The overall RAPT score was also noted to be significantly associated with a facility discharge, and patients that scored below a 9 were more likely to be discharged to a facility, which is consistent with previous total joint arthroplasty studies [ 14 25 27 The overall results of this study indicate that patient reported mental health, mobility, and social support were the primary factors associated with a facility discharge. The results of this study also demonstrated that in most cases the use of preoperative patient reported outcomes either alone or in combination with standard clinical metrics provided a better understanding of risk for patient discharge disposition. Therefore, this study also emphasizes both the need for and utility of a robust collection of preoperative patients reported outcomes. Patients that self-identified as having poor mental health via the PROMIS, could potentially benefit from additional points of contact during the preoperative and recovery phases, with medical staff (e.g. nurse navigators) to reassure them and answer questions in an effort to reduce anxiety and thus possibly reduce facility discharges. Patients self-reporting poor preoperative mobility could potentially benefit from preoperative physical therapy interventions, to improve mobility prior to their surgical intervention. For patients with limited social support, knowing this at the preoperative visit could provide ample time to plan for a nonroutine discharge for the patient, and thus reduce the potential for extended in hospital stays. The findings of this study should be used to improve preoperative planning for postsurgical care, and aid in shared decision-making conversations between the surgeon and patient. This study is not without limitations. The study demographics were relatively homogenous and thus may not represent a generalizable sample. Furthermore, the study inclusion criteria required that patients complete their preoperative patient reported outcomes, and thus this may have led to unintended selection bias. It is also important to note that the number of patients discharged to a facility, 41, was a relatively small cohort. This could significantly influence the generalizability of this study’s findings; therefore, future work is necessary to not only to confirm these findings, but also to expand on these findings to develop a predictive model. Additionally, our institution has a robust preoperative screening and optimization program; thus, the outcomes of this study may be influenced by this program, and could be a reason that some medical comorbidities noted in other studies as a risk were not found in this study as well. Furthermore, the multivariate regression analysis presented in this work only explains around 31% of the variability related to a facility discharge. Therefore, additional work is necessary to identify additional variables to improve the predictive nature of a future model. Conclusion In short, as lumbar spine procedures become increasingly more common ensuring quality of care while heralding fiscal responsibility is a primary goal of medical institutions, providers, and payers. Although facility discharges are uncommon following elective, 1 or 2 level lumbar fusions, they do represent a significant financial burden and substantially increased risk of poor postoperative outcomes. Therefore, investigating ways to identify and prevent patients from being discharged to a facility is of paramount importance. Special attention to patient self-reported mental wellness, mobility, and social support during the preoperative assessments using standard patient reported outcome tools can inform the likelihood of being discharged to a skilled nursing facility, with greater accuracy than clinically observed metrics alone.
